TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . He is a selfemployed entrepreneur .

CARDINAL . In his capacity as an entrepreneur , the applicant received a subsidy for the creation of a number of positions of employment deemed “ socially desirable ” . The subsidy was paid to him on terms specified in a contract with ORG úrad práce ) .

CARDINAL . NORP In a decision of CARDINAL DATE the ORG ( Daňový úrad ) found that the applicant had breached the abovementioned contract by failing to fill all the positions . The applicant was therefore ordered to return CARDINAL GPE korunas ( SKK ) of the subsidy and to pay SKK CARDINAL,CARDINAL by way of a financial penalty .
CARDINAL . NORP The period for appealing against the decision was DATE from the date of service .
CARDINAL . The written version of the decision was sent to the applicant through the postal service , to be served on him in person ( do vlastných rúk ) .

However , after repeated attempts to do so had proved unsuccessful the decision was deposited with the local post office and a notice was left in the applicant ’s mailbox to the effect that he could collect the decision there within DATE .
Should the applicant not collect the decision within that period , as proved to be the case , it was to be deemed to have been served on him by force of a legal presumption on DATE .

CARDINAL . The question of when the decision of CARDINAL DATE became final and binding ( právoplatnosť ) was not subject to full administrative or judicial examination . However , the authorities took the view that it had become final and binding on DATE , by operation of the presumption mentioned in the preceding paragraph . At that time the applicant had no legal representation .
CARDINAL . Under a legal - assistance contract of DATE , the applicant retained the services of a lawyer to provide him with general legal assistance , including representation in litigation .

CARDINAL . Being a member of ORG , the lawyer was under a duty conscientiously to defend her clients’ rights and diligently to apply all legal means available for the assertion of their interests and to have taken out and to maintain professional liability insurance ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant paid a visit to ORG , accompanied by his lawyer . It was on this occasion that the applicant obtained the decision of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) by collecting it from ORG in person .
CARDINAL . On DATE , through his lawyer , the applicant challenged the decision of CARDINAL DATE by way of an administrativelaw action ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . Simultaneously , also through the lawyer , the applicant requested an extraordinary review of the impugned decision by ORG ( PERSON daňové riaditeľstvo ) outside the framework of appellate proceedings ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . In his request , the applicant argued , inter alia , that he had in fact complied with the terms on which he had been provided with the subsidy .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG modified the decision of DATE in that it reduced the amount of the subsidy to be repaid to SKK CARDINAL,CARDINAL and the penalty payment to SKK CARDINAL . In the proceedings leading up to that decision the applicant ’s lawyer officially acted as his legal representative . Although it was open to her , the lawyer filed no administrative appeal against it on the applicant ’s behalf .
CARDINAL . ORG subsequently relieved the applicant of the duty to pay any more than SKK CARDINAL,CARDINAL in penalties .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( PERSON súd ) declared the applicant ’s administrative - law action ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) inadmissible and discontinued the proceedings . In the proceedings leading up to that decision the applicant ’s lawyer officially acted as his legal representative .

CARDINAL . ORG found that the applicant had failed to fulfil the statutory admissibility requirement of exhausting ordinary remedies by lodging an administrative appeal ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) and , as appropriate , by challenging the decision on the administrative appeal by way of a fresh administrativelaw action ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . In so far as there might have been any misgivings as to the way in which the impugned decision had been served on the applicant and , consequently , as to when the period for lodging an administrative appeal had expired , ORG held :

“ The court dealing with the action of CARDINAL DATE can not examine whether the defendant served the impugned decision [ on the applicant ] in accordance with LAW . This question may be examined only by the appellate administrative agency , in the context of an [ administrative ] appeal against the decision of the defendant .

Should the [ applicant ] have been of the opinion that the decision by the defendant was not served on him through the postal service in accordance with LAW , it was open to him to challenge that decision by means of an [ administrative ] appeal within the period for appealing , namely DATE from the collection of that decision in person from the defendant on DATE . The question whether the decision by the defendant was served on the applicant in accordance with LAW and , as the case may be , whether the [ applicant ] lodged his [ administrative ] appeal against the decision by the defendant within the statutory time - limit would have to be resolved by the administrative agency dealing with the appellate proceedings . Upon receipt of the decision of the appellate administrative agency on his appeal , it was open to the [ applicant ] to proceed as indicated above . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a civil action against the lawyer with the ORG ( ORG súd ) . He alleged that the lawyer had breached her duty of care by failing to use all remedies , in particular administrative appeals against the decisions of DATE and DATE , followed – as the case may be - by administrativelaw actions .

CARDINAL . The applicant argued , inter alia , that , in a judgment of DATE in an unrelated but similar case ORG ( Najvyšší súd ) had found for the plaintiff and had quashed the impugned decisions of the tax authorities .

CARDINAL . The applicant sought an order for payment of SKK CARDINAL,CARDINAL in damages . This sum represented the total amount that he had to pay back to the tax authorities . In the course of the proceedings the applicant reduced his claim by SKK CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the action and ordered the applicant to pay the defendant ’s costs .

CARDINAL . Referring to ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , ORG observed that the applicant ’s lawyer had not lodged an administrative appeal against the decision of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and that , consequently , ORG had no jurisdiction to deal with the applicant ’s administrative - law action .
CARDINAL . ORG also noted that the applicant ’s lawyer could have challenged the decision of DATE by means of an administrative appeal , but had not done so .
CARDINAL . ORG concluded that the lawyer had indeed breached her professional duties in that she had failed to use all available legal means for the protection of the applicant ’s interests .

CARDINAL . NORP However , no causal link could be established between that breach and the applicant ’s loss since it was unknown how the case would have proceeded on the merits had all the ordinary remedies been applied .

An administrative appeal against the decision of DATE fell to be determined by ORG . An administrative - law action against the decision of CARDINAL DATE fell to be determined by ORG sitting as an administrative tribunal . Relying on LAW , ORG concluded that the ordinary courts had no jurisdiction to take the place of these bodies and to pre - empt the outcome of the proceedings before them .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment following the hearing of an appeal by the applicant . ORG observed that the ordinary courts held no power of review as regards the substantive aspect of administrative decisions . It held that , similarly , the ordinary courts could not be a substitute for administrative agencies and tribunals by determining matters of substance within the latter ’s jurisdiction .

CARDINAL . ORG denied leave to appeal on points of law on the grounds that no issue of particular legal significance was involved and that the matter was the subject of well - established case - law , although this was not referred to in any detail .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint under LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) with ORG ( Ústavný súd ) . He argued that the dismissal of his action for damages had violated his rights of access to a court under LAW and to judicial or other legal protection under LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared the complaint inadmissible . The decision was served on the applicant on DATE .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court was of the view that the outcome of the applicant ’s action for damages hinged on a point of law that fell under the jurisdiction of the ordinary courts and had already been decided there . The ordinary courts , in particular ORG , had supported the decision with exhaustive , relevant and sufficient reasoning . There was no appearance of any constitutionally relevant arbitrariness or irregularity and the applicant ’s complaint was accordingly manifestly ill - founded .

CARDINAL . The applicant requested ORG to exercise his discretionary powers to challenge the judgment of DATE on the applicant ’s behalf by way of an extraordinary appeal on points of law on similar grounds to those raised in the applicant ’s constitutional complaint .
CARDINAL . In a letter of DATE the public prosecution service informed the applicant that it fully endorsed the ordinary court ’s reasoning and consequently , his request was dismissed .

CARDINAL . The “ right to judicial and other legal protection ” is laid down in Section ( Oddiel ) Seven of Part ( PERSON ) CARDINAL , dealing with “ basic rights and freedoms ” . The relevant part of DATE provides as follows :

“ CARDINAL . Everyone shall be able to assert his or her rights in a procedure provided for by a statute before an independent and impartial court of law and , in cases defined by a statute , before another organ of GPE .
CARDINAL . Conditions and details of judicial and other legal protection shall be provided for by a statute . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides :

“ CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court shall decide on complaints by natural or legal persons alleging a violation of their fundamental rights or freedoms ... unless the protection of such rights and freedoms falls within the jurisdiction of a different court .

CARDINAL . NORP If ORG finds a complaint justified , it shall deliver a decision stating that a person ’s rights or freedoms as set out in paragraph CARDINAL have been violated by a final decision , specific measure or other act and shall quash such decision , measure or act . If the violation that has been found is the result of a failure to act , ORG may order [ the authority ] which has violated the rights or freedoms to take the necessary action . At the same time it may remit the case to the authority concerned for further proceedings , order such authority to refrain from violating the fundamental rights and freedoms ... or , where appropriate , order those who have violated the rights or freedoms set out in paragraph CARDINAL to restore the situation to that existing prior to the violation .
CARDINAL . NORP In its decision on a complaint ORG may grant appropriate financial compensation to the person whose rights under paragraph CARDINAL have been violated . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides :
“ The interpretation and application of constitutional laws , acts of parliament and other generally binding statutes must be in accordance with LAW . ”
CARDINAL . The general rule on liability for damage is laid down in Article CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL of which provides :
“ Everyone shall be liable for any damage he or she causes by breach of statutory duty . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL reads as follows :

“ CARDINAL . In the exercise of his or her profession , an advocate is bound to uphold the LAW , acts of parliament and regulations issued for their implementation and , within their boundaries , to follow the client ’s instructions .

CARDINAL . An advocate is bound to protect the rights and lawful interests of the person he or she represents , to act conscientiously in doing so , diligently to use all legal means and to apply what he or she considers useful according to his or her conscience and the client ’s instructions .
CARDINAL . An advocate is bound to see to it that the legal assistance rendered is purposeful and economical . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant part of section DATE provides :

“ CARDINAL . An advocate is liable to his or her client for damage that he or she has caused in connection with the exercise of his or her profession ; this liability extends to damage caused by his or her trainee advocate ( koncipient ) or employee .

CARDINAL . An advocate shall be released from liability under subsection CARDINAL if he or she shows that the damage could not have been prevented with all efforts that may be expected of him or her . ”
CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL :

“ Before the commencement of the exercise of his or her profession , the advocate is bound to furnish to the Bar a professional liability insurance policy . This insurance must be valid throughout the period of the exercise of the advocate ’s profession . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL defines the jurisdiction of the ordinary courts . It provides :

“ CARDINAL . Courts in civil proceedings shall examine and decide upon disputes and other legal matters which stem from relations under civil law , labour law , family law , commercial law and economic law , provided that an act of parliament does not confer jurisdiction on other authorities .

CARDINAL . Courts in civil proceedings shall also review the lawfulness of decisions of public administrative authorities and the lawfulness of decisions , measures and other actions by public - power authorities , provided that an act of parliament does not confer jurisdiction on other authorities .
CARDINAL . Other matters may be examined and decided upon by courts in civil proceedings if an act of parliament so provides . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL defines which decisions are binding upon courts in civil proceedings . It provides :

“ CARDINAL . A court shall be bound by a decision by ORG as to the compatibility of a statute with LAW , an act of parliament or an international treaty binding upon GPE ... A court shall also be bound by a decision of ORG or ORG which concerns a question of fundamental human rights or freedoms . Moreover , a court shall be bound by a decision of the competent authorities that a criminal offence , a minor offence or another administrative offence punishable under special statute has been committed and by whom , as well as by a decision concerning personal status , the inception and winding up of a company and the entry of [ information on ] registered capital [ in ORG ] ; a court shall , however , not be bound by a decision taken in summary minor - offence proceedings ( blokové konanie ) .

CARDINAL . Other than that , questions falling to be decided by other authorities may be decided upon by a court directly . However , should such a question have been decided upon by the competent authority , the civil court shall adopt its decision ( vychádza z neho ) . ”

CARDINAL . Under LAW ( d ) , civil proceedings can be reopened where the ORG has found a violation of the requesting party ’s Convention rights and where serious consequences of the violation have not been adequately redressed by the award of just satisfaction .

CARDINAL . In the new decision in a reopened matter , the court determines issues relating to the reimbursement of the costs that the parties incurred both in the original and in the reopened proceedings ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The possibility of disregarding failure to comply with a time - limit is laid down in LAW , the relevant part of which provides :

“ CARDINAL . NORP The administrative authority may disregard a failure to comply with a time - limit ( lehota ) for serious reasons , provided that the party to the proceedings makes a request to that effect within DATE of DATE when the reasons for the failure [ to comply with the time - limit ] cease to exist , and that [ the party ] rectifies the omission within the same time - limit . CARDINAL . Failure to comply with a time - limit can not be disregarded after DATE has elapsed from DATE when the action should have been taken . ”
CARDINAL . An administrative appeal is normally to be lodged within DATE of DATE when the decision challenged is served ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . In DATE after an administrative decision becomes final and binding , it may be quashed or amended ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) upon a review by an administrative agency at the nearest level above the agency that issued the decision , of the higher agency ’s own motion or on an application by a third party ( LAW ) .
